Sporting shooter chef, Mark Gilchrist, is

One of the student's fathers owns this farm

we are going to have another couple of small

Because we are local there are few of us who

So when Scotland sends down its farmers the

Above all they are out to do what every shooter

It's more about having a good day out walking

176.text:
We are on shooting Captain Rory's farm, walking

Although everyone is grateful to Rory and

Rory has to do what he promised himself he

You promised you wouldn't do the pens, is

I've changed my mind, I think we will go back

which, says George, he will be hearing about

Two dead in the air at once you must be reasonably

Will had two down there so he will be going

Won't hear the end of that. No I had two quite

a few hens for breeding and not what. If it's

It has all turned into a marvellous morning's

Is that what a student shooting day should

I think it should be fun, I think these chaps

Girls as well and they all seem to shoot quite

Mark Gilchrist there. The thinking woman's

natural because hunting doesn't use any alien

Now, some of the UK's top long dog people
got in touch with us and asked whether we

446.text:
would like to go chasing rabbits with whippets
in the Yorkshire Dales. We said yes.

471.text:
Yorkshire Dales has a well known rabbit problem.
I am in Wenslydale and we are working whippets.

478.text:
If we don't do it the sheep go hungry and
what's more these guys love doing it. The

484.text:
walk up to the buries is a long hard trudge,
but imagine living up here the few sprigs

489.text:
of tough grass provide thin pickings for sheep
and rabbits alike. The day starts badly John

496.text:
loses a ferret finder collar in the first
bury and blames Darren.

499.text:
We could cheat and say there is a rabbit down
there.

509.text: So how much do those collars cost?

514.text: And how much does a ferret cost?

516.text:
But it is all about the animal's welfare and
that is why we have the collars on to begin

520.text:
with because again it isn't fair just because
the ferret is only worth pennies, you are

527.text:
not going to leave it in a place like this
just to fight for itself, that's why we put

535.text:
Very! I shall make sure I put my own collars
on next time.

539.text: Then things get better and rabbits start bolting.

542.text: Nigel and Darren are both nuts about whippets.

546.text:
I help run a farm called Poachers Rest Forum.
We just want to say we want people to see

552.text:
that whippets are great little dogs. 20 years
ago Brian Plumber was trying to create the

557.text:
all round lurcher he didn't have to look far,
the whippet was there they are the ant?? of

561.text:
the dog world they punch so far above their
own weight and they can do anything a good

566.text:
lurcher can do. Breed 2 whippets together
you get a whippet breed 2 lurchers together

571.text:
and you and you haven't got a clue what you
will get. You might pay a little more but

576.text:
you are saving money in the long run. You
are getting a great little dog which as you

580.text:
can see can cope with any condition here we
are in the Yorkshire Dales in places 8 or

585.text:
9” of snow the dogs weren't cold and shivering
and they just carried on doing their job as

591.text:
Darren is one of the top dog people in the
country. Nigel runs a Forum too.

596.text:
A friend of mine called Geoff Hutchins set
up the Forum a few years ago because basically

602.text:
it's quite a large population of owners who
use whippets now for work who might traditionally

611.text:
have owned lurchers I suppose and there wasn't
anywhere they could go to sound their opinions

616.text:
off a lot of the traditional forums were based
around showing and racing and there wasn't

622.text:
really anything available for owners or people
who like to work their whippets. So we started

627.text:
the Forum off and it has been a great success
to be honest. We have got members from all

630.text:
over the world and we work hand in hand with
a lot of the other forums, including Darren's.

634.text:
So of the 2 forums who has got the biggest
and best forum?

639.text:
Mine of course but I am sure Darren would
tell you his is the best as well.

644.text:
What is good is that the internet has brought
them all together. Darren from East Anglia,

650.text:
Nigel from the West Midlands and John from
here in north Yorkshire. There is a great

655.text:
deal to learn from all of them such as John's
method of paunching a rabbit without using

658.text:
a knife. He says his Dad wouldn't give him
a knife until he learnt to do it this way.

665.text:
With all their years of long dog experience
they have strong views about the criminal

669.text:
You are using whippets today but you are a

674.text:
Yes, I am an advocate of the lurcher. I am
more of a traditionalist than the 2 guys.

683.text:
But you like to draw a line between the illegal
use of lurchers and whippets.

689.text:
Yes, I would like to draw a line between illegal
coursing or even poaching. What a lot of people

696.text:
don't understand is that it is the farmer's
land, if you went and asked him I would say

702.text:
a good 8 times out of 10 he would let you
on because you are providing a service, but

709.text:
if you pull up at a gate and climb over he
doesn't know you are there, the implications

714.text:
of you having an accident on his land then
he has to come out, he's worried about his

722.text:
sheep, he's worried about his cattle are you
going to leave gates open. He just needs to

730.text:
Nice hat John! Always glad to advertise our
friends at BASC. Now we would not be ferreting

736.text:
if we did not lose a ferret and there are
always one or two who linger underground while

740.text:
we are waiting on the surface. The last rabbit
from this series of buries has 2 ferrets attached

745.text:
to it. The Countryside Alliance campaigns
for all fieldsports. We are committed to putting

751.text:
the hare back on the quarry list for whippets,

758.text:
February is a great month to get on top of
wood pigeons. The birds are mature and every

772.text:
one you knock down counts as it prevents their
future offspring from damaging crops later

777.text:
in the year. Team Wild Killer and Wildy are
in the middle of one of their busiest pigeon

782.text:
shooting months in the year. Today they are
on a farm in Staffordshire and they are out

787.text:
to protect Farmer Fontys precious rape crop
from this winged menace.

790.text:
We have been watching this field for a couple
of days now and there a quite a lot of wood

795.text:
pigeons coming in and feeding on it so we
are going to give it a go this morning and

798.text: see if we can get some down with the decoys.

800.text:
The first job is setting out the pattern,
drawing those pigeons in like moths to a flame.

806.text: Wildy looks after the real birds on the whirly.

808.text:
In proper Blue Peter fashion we always carry
a few in the freezer, I fetched them out the

813.text:
freezer last night so we can put them on the
magnet so that we're not waiting for anything

815.text:
coming in to have a shot so when we are set
and ready to rock we are ready to rock, not

819.text:
waiting for anything to do the magnets or
the dead bird cradles that we have got here.

824.text:
So I am going to whack these on now before
we put the plastic ones out. They'll see the

828.text:
other pigeons going round on the magnet and
on the dead bird cradles and think wow dinner

832.text:
time look at those boys over there and then
they come. So it's just moving them into the

837.text:
pattern and will hopefully getting them all
around here. The ones that are crossing over

843.text:
on the flight line will bring the others in
where we want to shoot them.

849.text: Killer is in charge of the plastic ones.

851.text:
We have got some flock coated decoys here
they are like other decoys but they have a

856.text:
flock coating on them which stops the sun
shining or bright light shining back off them.

861.text:
It takes the glare off them and makes them
more realistic. We are going to put these

865.text:
out in a horse shoe pattern, the idea being
we will bring the birds straight in, straight

869.text:
down the middle of us, straight to the shooting
zone. Putting these birds up today on a spring

874.text:
loaded peg, just adds a bit of movement the
idea being you want to get as much movement

879.text:
into your decoy pattern as well that's why
we have the whirlies the flappers and these.

885.text:
Decoys into the wind facing into the wind,
so that any wind catches the bird and gives

890.text:
a slight bit movement which makes it more
attractive to the passing pigeons.

894.text:
This is not a kit light sport. The boys have
a pile of equipment to take into the field.

900.text:
Once there everything has its place. However,
this new lightweight hide could save you lugging

906.text:
round a few extra pounds with its special
telescopic legs.

910.text:
It is just a case of unlatching these at the
back, sliding the hide up, clipping the latches

920.text:
back down again, so putting them all up together
at the same time, making sure you don't pull

929.text:
them out of the ground and there you have
one half of a pigeon hide.

937.text:
Decoys should face more or less into the wind
and the hide must be a masterpiece of camouflage.

941.text:
It is a good thing the boys are top to toe
in real tree.

946.text: So does Keith have trouble with dressing himself?

950.text:
All the time that is why we have to take Carol
everywhere with us. It's true.

955.text:
When everything is in its place and the countryside
has settled back down the pigeons start pouring

961.text:
in. There is little food at this time of year
the birds go for anything that looks promising

968.text:
and these decoys are full of promise. Of course
it is not all hard graft and the banter between

974.text: the lads is as regular as the shot.

977.text:
OK we've just been to look for the one that
Steven shot, we found a patch of feathers

985.text:
up there where he stopped, got his breath
back had a bit of a laugh then carried on,

989.text:
there was no body, so a no kill, but that
is pigeon shooting, better than being at work

997.text:
Having 2 people in a hide is sociable, but
it has its safety issues too of which Killer

1013.text:
There are some good shots and some excellent
shots which of course the camera misses.

1019.text:
Good shot – this camera is a bit ropey today
it's missed some of your shots.

1027.text:
Yes, well it's good like that because I like
Nick he's a nice man, but professional? We

1032.text: use the word loosely round here!

1035.text:
At least Bracken is on hand to prove all the
birds did really hit the deck.

1039.text:
We take Bracken where ever we go she is very
reliable, very steady in the hide, one of

1044.text:
the best Springers we have ever known in fact
she even drives Keith home from the pub every

1047.text: now and again she is that clever.

1049.text:
There are moments to keep a gun safe and there
are moments when a gun needs to be dangerous

1054.text:
such as when a pigeon is coming into the pattern
and in those dangerous moments it is good

1059.text: to know that you have got the right gun.

1061.text:
Today we have been shooting this Armsan A612
semi auto shotgun. Imported to the UK through

1068.text:
Viking Arms. Cracking bit of kit comes up
well no recoil and for a budget priced shotgun

1075.text:
it really is good. We both shot it today we
both shot fairly well with the gun, got a

1080.text: decent bag very impressed with it.

1083.text:
So, what did Team Wild think of the shooting
today.

1086.text:
We have had a great day we have shot 32 pigeons,
we have still got 2 to pick which went off

1091.text:
into an ash tree, we watched them we hope
they will be dead under there we will go and

1095.text:
fetch them in a bit. So we have had a great
day shooting. Both had good fun, we are going

1101.text:
to go round now and make sure we have picked
up all the cartridges, all the bags, everything,

1105.text:
make it nice and tidy and leave the ground
as we found it.

1109.text:
For more about the Armsan shotgun the guys
are using visit www.vikingarms.com. Team Wild

1117.text:
UK will be back with avengence next Wednesday

1130.text:
How did you get into shooting? Well here's
how some of our top shots did it.

1143.text:
Here are the top reasons why people say they
don't want to try shooting: I don't have a

1148.text:
licence, I don't have a gun, I'm frightened
of guns, I couldn't hit a barn door and you

1152.text:
need to start shooting when you are a kid.
Sound familiar? Well here are 2 people who

1157.text:
started shooting less than a dozen years ago
and they are both representing their country

1161.text:
and winning medals in the sport. Abbey Burton
won silver at the Common Wealth Games in 2010

1168.text:
held in India. Peter Wilson earnt England
an extra Olympic place when he won silver

1173.text: at the 2011 Shooting World Cup in Chile.

1176.text:
Well I started shooting with my Grandfather,
he basically took me out and I shot a plastic

1183.text:
milk carton on the floor with a 4/10 so that
is how I started and then he sent me on for

1190.text:
lessons up at E J Churchills in High Wycombe.
I was then spotted by a county representative

1198.text:
which then got me into trap shooting. I then
met some friends in trap shooting and then

1203.text:
went on to the GB selections and then went
on to compete as a junior abroad.

1207.text:
I was mad keen on cricket and squash at school,
they were certainly my main sports. I damaged

1213.text:
my shoulder, I dislocated my left shoulder
which broke the nerves and I had to have a

1218.text:
number of operations which meant I had to
give up every sort of sport I was involved

1222.text:
with at that time. I had shot before, but
never in a serious capacity. The physios were

1227.text:
very keen that I held the weight in my left
hand so shooting was a great sport to do.

1232.text:
Every Wednesday we were going out with the
school and shooting. The physios were keen

1236.text:
that I carried on, so I carried on and when
I came back to everything else I was pretty

1239.text:
rubbish, so I decided to carry on with shooting
and I was really enjoying it by then and I

1244.text:
left school as national champion and was just
enjoying my shooting.

1249.text: Stevan Walton is another double trap shooter.

1252.text:
I've got a friend who owns a shooting ground
on his land just down the road from where

1256.text:
I live in Redditch, just went there as a kid
and progressed to county level shooting down

1260.text:
the line and sporting, then on to England
shooting down the line and then Great Britain

1266.text:
George Digweed is probably the best known
clay pigeon shooter in the world. In a competition

1271.text:
career spanning 4 decades he has won 19 world
titles in the discipline of sporting and FITASC

1277.text: which is what most people shoot in the UK.

1280.text:
I started when I was about 12, 12 to 14. We
had a family butchers business and when Grandfather

1286.text:
used to take me out shooting I had a 4/10
to carry empty. In my view I was given correct

1292.text:
grounding and shooting went on from there
really and I became competitive. I am competitive

1299.text:
by nature in everything I do and I wanted
to take clay pigeon shooting further as I

1305.text:
thought I possibly had a talent in it and
the rest is history really.

1310.text:
How old were you when you won your first memorable
competition?

1315.text:
For me my first major win was to win the Home
International Chief Championship, shooting

1320.text:
200 straight in 1986 at Melton Mowbray Gun
Club. That for me was really my career defining

1327.text:
moment, which said to me as I was driving
home, I can do this at the top level.

1335.text:
Clay pigeon shooting is a broad church covering
all shotgun sports. Whether you do it at the

1341.text:
top level like George, Stevan, Abbey and Pete
or whether you simply enjoy a few shots around

1346.text:
a clay ground with a few mates, it is fun
and just as accessible as golf or tennis.

1352.text:
To answer those people who say they don't
want to try shooting, you don't need a licence,

1356.text:
you don't have to own a gun, which are nothing
to be frightened of. You don't need to start

1361.text:
shooting as a kid. Many people take it up
late in life and you can hit a target a lot

1366.text:
smaller than a barn door after just one lesson.
Shooting takes a few minutes to learn and

1372.text:
a lifetime to master. The CPSA is the governing
body for clay pigeon shooting in England.

1378.text:
It is a membership organisation committed
to bringing more people into the sport, as

1385.text:
Trying to attract people into the sport you
don't want to frighten them by thinking they

1389.text:
have got to achieve a certain level of attainment
from day 1, nobody does. Interestingly enough

1396.text:
we were talking with George Digweed at the
Bisley Live very recently and he was advocating

1400.text:
encouraging people to come into the sport
at any level, not necessarily with the aspiration

1405.text:
of achieving gold at the Common Wealth Games,
but actually just get a taste of the sport

1411.text:
and find out what discipline of clay shooting
suits them and then further their abilities

1415.text:
there to the level that suits them. Again
it doesn't have to be to competitive level

1420.text:
For more about how to start shooting go to
www.cpsa.co.uk
